    • Multiple imputations by two-level model

Multiple imputations by two-level model

Source: vignettes/Two-level-mi.Rmd
Two-level-mi.Rmd

Set-up and notation

Suppose there are mm studies to evaluate the diagnostic accuracy of some test. For the iith study, let

  • TPi\mbox{TP}_i: number of true positives
  • FNi\mbox{FN}_i: number of false negatives
  • FPi\mbox{FP}_i: number of false positives
  • TNi\mbox{TN}_i: number of true negatives

These are the data we wish to collect for each i=1,…,mi=1,\ldots, m. Write Ni=TPi+FNiN_i=\mbox{TP}_i+\mbox{FN}_i, the number of cases; N‾i=FPi+TNi\bar N_i=\mbox{FP}_i + \mbox{TN}_i, the number of non-cases; and ni=Ni+N‾in_i = N_i + \bar N_i, the total sample size.

Let pip_i denote the sensitivity, qiq_i the specificity, and πi\pi_i the prevalence of cases in the iith study. If there is no missing data, we can easily estimate them by p̂i=TPi/Ni\hat p_i=\mbox{TP}_i/N_i, q̂i=TNi/N‾i\hat q_i=\mbox{TN}_i/\bar N_i, and π̂i=Ni/ni\hat\pi_i=N_i/n_i, respectively. We can also feed the entire data (TPi,FNi,FPi,TNi)(\mbox{TP}_i, \mbox{FN}_i, \mbox{FP}_i, \mbox{TN}_i)(i=1,…,m)(i=1,\ldots, m) into any standard software, e.g., mada (Sousa-Pinto 2022), for meta-analysis.

Methods

A motivating example

Consider the scenario where there are no non-cases in some study ii, so FNi\mbox{FN}_i, TNi=\mbox{TN}_i=NA. An example:

library(mtroc)
uts
#>            TP FN FP  TN
#> Ahn        19  0 NA  NA
#> Bock        5  5  2  17
#> Chung       5  0 48 114
#> Cordoba    21  1 NA  NA
#> Espinosa    5  0 NA  NA
#> Haliloglu   3  0  1  73
#> Langer     57 17 NA  NA
#> Liberman    6  0 NA  NA
#> Nishanova  26  4 NA  NA
#> Obenauer    2  2  0  23
#> Oh          9  0 NA  NA
#> Qian       50  1 63  92
#> Reyes      32  1 NA  NA
#> Robbins     4  0 17 101
#> Taskin     47  0 NA  NA
#> Taylor     21  0 NA  NA
#> Yang       21  0 NA  NA
#> Myers      33  0 NA  NA
#> Taron      19  0 NA  NA
#> Son         6  0  6  23
#> Jafari     31  0 NA  NA
#> Wang      110 18 NA  NA

We aim to fill in the missing values of FNi\mbox{FN}_i and TNi\mbox{TN}_i by multiple imputations (MI).

Two-level random-effects models

We can think of the data as generated in two stages. First, with total sample size nin_i, the relative size of NiN_i vs N‾i\bar N_i is determined by prevalence πi\pi_i. Second, given NiN_i and N‾i\bar N_i, the relative size of TPi\mbox{TP}_i vs FNi\mbox{FN}_i, and that of FPi\mbox{FP}_i vs TNi\mbox{TN}_i, are determined by sensitivity pip_i and specificity qiq_i, respectively. This leads us to posit a two-level model for prevalence and for sensitivity-specificity relationship: the first allows us to impute the size of cases or non-cases; the second to impute specificity from sensitivity (or vice versa).

To account for between-study heterogeneity, we add study-specific random effects on the logit scale of each model. Write logit(x)=log{x/(1−x)}\mbox{logit}(x)=\log\{x/(1-x)\}. logit(πi)=α0+εilogit(qi)=(β0+b0i)+(β1+b1i)logit(pi),\begin{align}\tag{1} \mbox{logit}(\pi_i)&= \alpha_0 + \varepsilon_i\\ \mbox{logit}(q_i) &= (\beta_0 + b_{0i}) + (\beta_1 + b_{1i})\mbox{logit}(p_i), \end{align} where (α0,β0,β1)(\alpha_0, \beta_0, \beta_1) are fixed effects, εi∼N(0,σπ2)\varepsilon_i\sim N(0, \sigma_\pi^2), bi=(b0i,b1i)T∼N(0,Σb)b_i=(b_{0i}, b_{1i})^{T}\sim N(0, \Sigma_b), and εi⊥bi\varepsilon_i\perp b_i. In particular, model (1) maximally allows for study-to-study variations in the prevalence and in the (generally negative) correlation between sensitivity and specificity.

Let 𝒞\mathcal C denote the set of indices where complete data are observed. Thus for each i∈𝒞ii\in\mathcal C_i, we have complete estimates of π̂\hat\pi, p̂i\hat p_i, and q̂i\hat q_i. Using them as pseudo-observations in (1), we can estimate the parameters by α̂=mean{logit(π̂i):i∈𝒞}\hat\alpha=\mbox{mean}\{\mbox{logit}(\hat\pi_i): i\in\mathcal C\}, σ̂π2=var{logit(π̂i):i∈𝒞}\hat\sigma_\pi^2=\mbox{var}\{\mbox{logit}(\hat\pi_i): i\in\mathcal C\}, β̂=\hat\beta= least-squares estimate of logit(q̂i) vs logit(p̂i)\mbox{logit}(\hat q_i) \mbox{ vs }\mbox{logit}(\hat p_i)(i∈𝒞)(i\in\mathcal C). Finally, Σb\Sigma_b can be estimated by Σ̂b=|𝒞|var̂(β̂)\hat\Sigma_b=|\mathcal C|\hat{\mbox{var}}(\hat\beta), where |𝒞||\mathcal C| is the number of studies in 𝒞\mathcal C and var̂(β̂)\hat{\mbox{var}}(\hat\beta) is the estimated variance matrix of β̂\hat\beta under standard least squares.

Imputation process

For any i∈𝒞¯={i=1,…,m:FNi and TNi are missing}i\in\overline{\mathcal C}=\{i=1,\ldots, m: \mbox{FN}_i \mbox{ and } \mbox{TN}_i \mbox{ are missing}\}, we only know NiN_i and p̂i\hat p_i, and will have to impute FNi\mbox{FN}_i and TNi\mbox{TN}_i. We do so multiple times by drawing random effects from model (1), in order to account for the certainty in the missing values.

At the jjth imputation, for each i∈𝒞¯i\in\overline{\mathcal C}:

  • Draw εi(j)∼N(0,σ̂π2)\varepsilon_i^{(j)}\sim N(0, \hat\sigma_\pi^2); bi(j)∼N(0,Σ̂b)b_i^{(j)}\sim N(0,\hat\Sigma_b);
  • Compute π̂i(j)\hat\pi_i^{(j)} and q̂i(j)\hat q_i^{(j)} by inserting α̂0\hat\alpha_0, εi(j)\varepsilon_i^{(j)}, β̂\hat\beta, and bi(j)b_i^{(j)} in model (1);
  • Impute the missing values by N‾i(j)=Ni(1−π̂i(j))/π̂i(j)\bar N_i^{(j)}= N_i(1-\hat\pi_i^{(j)})/\hat\pi_i^{(j)}, FNi(j)=N‾i(j)(1−q̂i(j))\mbox{FN}_i^{(j)} = \bar N_i^{(j)}(1-\hat q_i^{(j)}), and TNi(j)=N‾i(j)q̂i(j)\mbox{TN}_i^{(j)} = \bar N_i^{(j)}\hat q_i^{(j)}.

We thus obtain a completed dataset 𝒟(j)={(TPi,FNi,FPi(j),TNi(j)):i=1,…,m}, \mathcal D^{(j)}= \{(\mbox{TP}_i, \mbox{FN}_i, \mbox{FP}_i^{(j)}, \mbox{TN}_i^{(j)}): i=1,\ldots, m\}, where we define FPi(j)=FPi\mbox{FP}_i^{(j)}=\mbox{FP}_i and TNi(j)=TNi\mbox{TN}_i^{(j)}=\mbox{TN}_i for i∈𝒞i\in\mathcal C. Given 𝒟(j)\mathcal D^{(j)}, we can use standard software for meta-analysis to obtain a summary measure of diagnostic accuracy, say, the summary AUC, denoted by AUĈ(j)\hat{\mbox{AUC}}^{(j)}. We may also obtain its variance var̂(AUĈ(j))\hat{\mbox{var}}(\hat{\mbox{AUC}}^{(j)}).

Repeat the above for j=1,…,Jj =1,\ldots, J (e.g., J=500J=500). Then compute the multiply imputed AUC by AUĈ=J−1∑j=1JAUĈ(j), \hat{\mbox{AUC}}=J^{-1}\sum_{j=1}^J\hat{\mbox{AUC}}^{(j)}, and its variance by var̂(AUĈ)=J−1∑j=1J(AUĈ(j)−AUĈ)2⏟between-imputation+J−1∑j=1Jvar̂(AUĈ(j))⏟within-imputation. \hat{\mbox{var}}(\hat{\mbox{AUC}}) = \underbrace{J^{-1}\sum_{j=1}^J(\hat{\mbox{AUC}}^{(j)} -\hat{\mbox{AUC}})^2}_{\mbox{between-imputation}} + \underbrace{J^{-1}\sum_{j=1}^J\hat{\mbox{var}}(\hat{\mbox{AUC}}^{(j)})}_{\mbox{within-imputation}}. The above computations can be done on the logit scale of the AUC to improve their accuracy of approximation.

References

Sousa-Pinto, Philipp Doebler with contributions from Bernardo. 2022. “Mada: Meta-Analysis of Diagnostic Accuracy.” https://CRAN.R-project.org/package=mada.
